data.name: Enchanting
entries: Enchanting is a hard and expensive profession, but one eagerly pursued by many all the same. The makers of miracles, the craftsmen of wonder, no other profession holds the fascination of adventurers quite like Enchanter, for their domain encompasses the large majority of magical items.

An item need not pass through an enchanter's hands to be magical, indeed many a {@book Blacksmith|KTKCG|12} has forged a magical blade with the right materials, but the true wonder of enchantment is to turn the mundane magical. An enchanter can turn even the most base and commonplace item into something wonderful and powerful, and when given the head start of working with an already well crafted item can craft things of legend.

Many enchanters further specialize in subdomains such as {@book Scroll Scribing|KTKCG|15} or {@book Wand Whittling|KTKCG|16} for more specialized good that require more specialized tools, with many even pursuing such things as {@book Jewelry Crafting|KTKCG|22|Jewelcrafting} in order to create the precious items that most easily enchant, but the general field of Enchanting still covers a large swath of the wondrous.

{@item Scroll|KTKCG|Scrolls} are heavily featured as a component of nearly all magical items, forming the basis for the powerful enchantments that imbue them with their magic. These are templates of a sort, and thus the ability to craft {@item scroll|KTKCG|scrolls} with {@book Scroll Scribery|KTKCG|15} is often the most desired of the subdomains for an Enchanter.

entries.name: Quick Reference
entries: While each step will go into more depth, the quick reference allows you to at a glance follow the steps to make a magic item in its most basic form:

items: Select the magic item that you would like to craft from any of the {@book Magic Item Tables|KTKCG|14|Tables}.
Acquire the items listed in the materials column for that item.

Use your {@skill Arcana} skill to infuse the option using the number of hours listed in the Crafting Time column, or during a long rest using the {@action Craft|action|crafting camp action} if the crafting time is 2 hours or less.
For every 2 hours, make a crafting roll of {@dice 1d20} + your Intelligence modifier + your {@skill Arcana} proficiency.

On success, you mark 2 hours of completed time. Once the completed time is equal to the crafting time, the magic item is complete. On failure, the crafting time is lost and no progress has been made during the 2 hours. If you fail 3 times in a row, the crafting is a failure and all materials are lost.

entries.name: Related Skill & Ability Score
entries: Rather than any one tool, Enchanting primarily uses the {@skill Arcana} skill. Due to the subdomains of scrolls ({@book Scroll Scribing|KTKCG|15}) and runes ({@book Runecraft|KTKCG|20}) being part of enchanting, proficiency in {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|PHB} is often useful.

Enchanting uses your Intelligence modifier. While magic comes in many forms (Arcane, Primal, Divine) and many casters are able to control it with other aspects of their talent, the ability to systematically bind it into magic items requires a deep understanding of its inner workings that can only be accomplished through meticulous study and knowledge.

entries.name: Psionic Items
entries: The items listed on the {@table Psionic Items Table|KTKCG} is the exception to this rule. These are items infused with psionic power, and instead use the "{@skill Psionics|ktp}" skill, a skill that any psionic character can be considered proficient if not using special psionics rules.
These items are something of a subtype of enchanting, and may not exist in your setting if psionics aren't included. Consult your GM.

entries.name: Materials: Essences & Components
entries: The materials of enchanting are Essences and Components. {@item essence|KTKCG} come in three different types: Arcane, Primal, and Divine—as well as five rarities: common, uncommon, rare, very rare, and legendary. What an Essence is can vary greatly, as they are things of innate magic that is used to power the Enchanter's creations.

They could be organs of magical monsters (such as the heart of a dragon which would be a {@item rare primal essence|KTKCG}) or they can be synthesized from magical reagents into a magical compound. Components are a broad category of items ranging from the base item you are enchanting to any extraneous bits needed to be added. One unique component that is present in many enchantments is a {@item scroll|KTKCG|Spell Scroll} of various types of spells that form the basis of the sort of the magic the item has.

entries.name: Replacing Spell Scrolls
entries: A crafter that is capable of casting magic can replace the {@item scroll|KTKCG|spell scroll} in an enchantment with the ability to cast that spell, but when doing so they must cast that spell for each crafting check they make on that item. This is an exhausting process, draining their magic far more deeply than normal casting, and confers a level of {@condition exhaustion} each time this technique is used to replace a crafting check. If a magic item requires multiple {@item scroll|KTKCG|scrolls}, only one of them can be replaced in this way, though if an additional spell caster that can cast the necessary spell can assist you, they can replace a second {@item scroll|KTKCG}, though suffering the same penalty.

entries.name: Exhausting & Difficult Method
entries: This mechanic is intentionally quite difficult to use—even for casters that are capable of casting the spell. The typical process would be to make the scroll first to formalize their thoughts and process, laying down the patterns and templates for the magic item. It also removes a very costly gate in the process, so should not be easily bypassed.

entries.name: Crafting Roll
entries: Putting that together means that when you would like to enchant an item, your crafting roll is as follows:

entries.name: Success and Failure
entries: After you make a crafting roll, if you succeed, you make 2 hours of progress toward the total crafting time (and have completed one of the required checks for making an item).

Checks for Enchanting do not need to be immediately consecutive. If you fail three times in a row, all progress and materials are lost and can no longer be salvaged. Failure means that no progress is made during that time.
Once an item is started, even if no progress is made, the components reserved for that item can only be recovered via salvage.

entries.name: Enchanting Example and Walkthrough
entries: Caius the Wizard has a keen interest in magic items. At the start, all he has is the {@skill Arcana} skill and big dreams. Let's walk through how turn those into a magic item.
Caius the Wizard happens to be a level 4 wizard in this moment in time. Strangely, he's the only human in his party, and his lack of {@sense darkvision} has been holding them back.
So, Caius decides to embark on making a set of {@item Goggles of Night|DMG}. Let's follow his journey:

First, he'll need to gather that materials. He needs googles, a {@item scroll|KTKCG} of {@spell darkvision}, a {@item common primal essence|KTKCG}, and an {@item uncommon arcane essence|KTKCG}. Goggles are easily acquired from the local merchants for a few gold pieces, the rest will be a bit trickier.

A {@item common primal essence|KTKCG} isn't that hard to come by, and can be found by harvesting elementals, dragons, giants, or monstrosities, even at the humble 0–4 CR rating of monsters Caius has been dealing with.

The {@item uncommon arcane essence|KTKCG} will require a hunt. His party takes on a CR 5 undead, but on their {@dice d100}, they roll a 64... no luck, all that was left was some mangled bones and 3 {@item uncommon poisonous reagent|KTKCG|uncommon poisonous reagents}. After a few more tries, it seems luck isn't with them. Fortunately, Caius has a plan. That {@item uncommon poisonous reagent|KTKCG} he got can be combined with an {@item uncommon curative reagent|KTKCG} and {@item uncommon reactive reagent|KTKCG} in a simple 4 hour process with {@item Alchemist's supplies|PHB} and a head source ({@footnote page 181|This homebrew only has 147 pages...}).

Boiling them all down, he's left with some magical residue forming an {@item uncommon arcane essence|KTKCG}. Now all he needs is the {@item scroll|KTKCG} of {@spell darkvision}. Caius really should have this spell long since given his {@sense darkvision} shortcomings, but never got around to it. So Caius shells out 90 gp to buy a scroll of it. Not to learn it though, of course, as soon he'll never need that spell again!

All the pieces are assembled. As a level 4 Wizard with 16 Intelligence and proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill, Caius Enchanting Modifier is 2 (his {@skill Arcana} proficiency bonus) + 3 (his intelligence modifier), so is 5 total.

During his next long rest, Caius makes his first crafting check, and rolls a {@dice d20}! It's a 10. 10 + 5 = 15, so he as a success. He's 1/4th of the way done, but needs to spend the rest of that long rest sleeping.

The next day he rolls again, 6! That's only 11! One failure. The next night it's a 15 for a check of 20! That's a second success. Tragedy almost strikes with the next two checks being a 4 and 2, with results of 9 and 7 respectively, that's two more failures! All of his hard work is on the edge of being lost.

But Caius asks to take an extra long break at the next town. He uses the 4 hours to make his next check, taking a 10 on the roll to forestall disaster. As he wasn't too ambitious and the {@item Goggles of Night|KTKCG} are only {@dc 13}, that means by taking 10, Caius has a minimum check of a 15, and it's a pass. Feeling better, now that he's no longer one checked from the whole project failing, he makes his next check on the road, and gets an 18, for a total of 24. A fourth success, and he can take his watch that night with {@sense darkvision} at long last...
...unfortunately he'd been up too late working and fell asleep, so his party got ambushed anyway, but that's a story for another time!

Caius the Wizard now can see in the dark as well as any pointy eared elf or long bearded dwarf! It took a bit longer than he'd hoped, but now Caius has his very first shiny magic item made by his own hands!

entries.name: Contributed Items
entries: To expand the list beyond the SRD, the system includes items from talented creators like {@link Dungeon Strugglers|https://www.artstation.com/dungeon_strugglers} (DS), {@link Griffon's Saddlebag|https://www.thegriffonssaddlebag.com/} (GS), and {@link Spectre Creations|https://www.spectrecreations.com/} (TAG). These items are used with permission, and a tiny a fraction of their overall catalog. If you like the look of their stuff, you can find far more from them online.

entries.name: Psionic Items
entries: Psionic items are a special category of item that are powered by psionics. Some of them will will work for any user, some of the require the user to have psionic abilities.

table.name: Synthesizing Essences
footnotes: This process takes 4 hours, and requires {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} and a heat source.

outro.name: Special Cases Explained

items.name: {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Sorcerers}
entries: produce a type based on their subclass; {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Dragon|Draconic|PHB} or {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Wild|Wild|PHB} makes Primal, {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Divine Soul|Divine Soul|XGE} makes Divine, and {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Shadow|Shadow|XGE} makes Arcane.

items.name: {@class Warlock|PHB|Warlocks}
entries: likewise produce a type based on their subclass; {@class Warlock|PHB|Archfey|Archfey|PHB} makes Primal, {@class Warlock|PHB|Celestial|Celestial|XGE} makes Divine, and all others make Arcane.

items.name: {@class Occultist|KT:O}
entries: can produce any type, but takes 1.5x as long to produce an Essence in this manner. A GM can rule based on the special circumstances of a character their power source may be different than normal. This can stand in for {@class Occultist|KT:O|Shaman|Shaman|KT:O}, {@class Occultist|KT:O|Witch|Witch|KT:O}, or {@class Occultist|KT:O|Oracle|Oracle|KT:O} classes if you use those instead of {@class Occultist|KT:O}.

items.name: {@class Artificer (Revised)|ArtificerRevised|Inventor}
entries: can stand in for any half-arcane caster of a similar theme.
A half- or third-caster would generate essences at 1/2 or 1/3 their character level, respectively.

table.name: Alchemy Modifiers
intro: The following are alchemical modifiers that can be applied to a potion. All alchemical modifiers require approval from the GM if the modifier will work with a given potion or creation.
rows: Require two additional {@item reactive reagent|KTKCG|reactive reagents} of equal rarity to the rarest reagent of the potion. Rather than drinking it, when uncorked or broken (as an action) it effects all creatures in a 5-foot radius as if they'd consumed it.
Requires an {@item common divine essence|KTKCG}. Adds the effect of {@spell lesser restoration} to the potion.
Requires an {@item rare divine essence|KTKCG}. Adds the effect of {@spell greater restoration} to the potion.
Any fire damage the potion does becomes cold damage.
Requires an additional {@item common reactive reagent|KTKCG}. Expands the area of effect of any area of effect the potion has by 5 feet.

The effect of the potion becomes shrouded from magic such as {@spell identify}. You can make the potion appear as another potion of the same rarity. Another alchemist can identify it by making an Alchemy Check against your Alchemy DC.

table.name: Additional Materials
intro: You can simply load more reagents into any potion, increasing its potency in different ways, though it increases the difficulty. You can make a "custom potion" simply by using these modifiers with no base potion. When you do so, the base DC is 8.
rows: The potion restores +{@dice 1d4} hit points when consumed.
The potion deals +{@damage 1d4} fire damage when shattered (or consumed).
The potion deals +{@damage 1d4} poison damage when consumed.
The potion restores +{@dice 2d4} hit points when consumed.
The potion deals +{@damage 2d4} fire damage when shattered (or consumed).
The potion deals +{@damage 2d4} poison damage when consumed.
The potion restores +{@dice 3d4} hit points when consumed.
The potion deals +{@damage 3d4} fire damage when shattered (or consumed).
The potion deals +{@damage 3d4} poison damage when consumed.
{@item Very Rare Curative Reagent|KTKCG|Very Rare Curative}
The potion restores +{@dice 4d4} hit points when consumed.
{@item Very Rare Reactive Reagent|KTKCG|Very Rare Reactive}
The potion deals +{@damage 4d4} fire damage when shattered (or consumed).
{@item Very Rare Poisonous Reagent|KTKCG|Very Rare Poisonous}
The potion deals +{@damage 4d4} poison damage when consumed.
The potion restores +{@dice 5d4} hit points when consumed.
The potion deals +{@damage 5d4} fire damage when shattered (or consumed).
The potion deals +{@damage 5d4} poison damage when consumed.

outro.name: "Ice/Dark/Fire" Steel Ingots
entries: The names for Icesteel, Darksteel, and Firesteel are intentionally generic to better map to unique metals that might be present in your setting, and may have other names. Adamantine and Mithril tend to be widespread (and consequently open source metals), but other more unique metals may vary based on setting.

tables.caption: Step 1: Select one of...
tables.name: Step 1: Select one of...
intro: To create a weapon go through five steps to determine the final damage and properties of the weapon. Adding a {@dice d2} means increasing the die by one size (e.g. a {@dice d6} + {@dice d2} = {@dice d8}) and the converse for subtracting a {@dice d2}.

tables.caption: Step 2: Select one of...
tables.name: Step 2: Select one of...
rows: +{@dice d2} when wielded with two hands

tables.caption: Step 3: Select all that apply...
tables.name: Step 3: Select all that apply...
rows: No damage die cost if the weapon is light or has no other properties

tables.caption: Step 4: Set Damage Die/Dice...
tables.name: Step 4: Set Damage Die/Dice...
outro: You can divide your damage die into smaller dice that equal the same total. For example, a d12 can become 2d6 or be reduced again to 3d4. Each time you do this, the crafting Base DC increases by +1. You can't divide dice to be lower than d4.

tables.caption: Bonus Step: Modifiers and Materials
tables.name: Bonus Step: Modifiers and Materials
outro: You can additionally add {@table Material Modifiers|KTKCG} and {@table Crafting Modifiers|KTKCG} to template weapons. These modifiers may add additional properties as listed by the modifier, and their difficulty modifier is incorporated into the weapon.

items: Thrown can be ranged weapons instead of melee weapons. (Example: {@item Dart|PHB})
The GM can waive the restriction on heavy property requiring two-handed property but should be aware it opens the door to combining feats for great weapons with the use of shields.
Add one {@item short haft|KTKCG} for axes, maces or similar.
Weapons made of metal require a minimum of half an {@item ingot|KTKCG} (like a dagger), even if the table would reduce them zero.

table.name: Defensive Items
footnotes: Shields and bracers can't benefit from armor crafting modifications.

table.name: Miscellaneous Gear
footnotes: * The effects of a helmet are included in armor, this entry is largely to allow for standalone helmet creation for enchanters.

table.name: Components and Materials
footnotes: <sup>S</sup> Smelting ore requires specialized facilities. This can usually be accomplished in a fully equipped smithy, but consult your GM for where it might be appropriate. Adventurers rarely smelt their own ore, these are included primarily for informational purposes. Smelting magical ores may require more specialized facilities or locations.

table.name: Firearms
footnotes: Firearms and Thunder Cannons are not found in all settings. Consult your GM.

tables.caption: Martial Weapons
tables.name: Martial
footnotes: Custom Weapons are a bit more expensive than normal weapons. This is a reflection of their customization and greater difficulty to craft, is derived from their crafting DC.

table.name: Material Modifiers
rows: Weapons forged from Bronze are inferior, having −1 to attack and damage rolls. Gains the Fragile property.
Armor forged from bronze is inferior, having a −1 penalty to its AC. Gains the Fragile property.

Gains the "Special: Critical Strikes with this weapon permanently damage nonmagical weapons, shields or armor of the defending creature that are not forged from Adamantine (reducing the attack roll of a weapon or the AC of armor by 2)".
While you're wearing it, any critical hit against you becomes a normal hit.

A weapon with the heavy property forged from it loses the heavy property. If the weapon didn't have the heavy property, it gains the light property. The DC of an Enchanter applying an Enchantment to it is reduced by 4, and it always counts has having 1 {@item common essence|KTKCG} of any type as part of the craft.
If the armor normally imposes disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks or has a Strength requirement, the mithral version of the armor doesn't. Easier for Enchanters to Enchant.
You have advantage on attack rolls while in darkness wielding Darksteel weapons.
{@skill Perception} checks relying on sight have disadvantage against you when you are in dim light or darkness while wearing this armor.
A weapon forged from icesteel deals an extra {@damage 1d4} cold damage on hit.
Wearing armor forged from icesteel grants resistance to Fire damage.
A weapon forged from firesteel deals an extra {@damage 1d4} fire damage on hit.
Wearing armor forged from firesteel grants resistance to Cold damage.

table.name: Crafting Modifiers
footnotes: <sup>MW</sup> Masterwork: Failing a crafting roll for Masterwork doesn't cause a failure, but the resulting weapon is only a Masterwork if all crafting rolls succeed pass the DC of Masterwork. An item is automatically masterwork if every roll qualified for a Masterwork version.

<sup>DR</sup> Damage Reduction: While you are wearing armor, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage that you take from nonmagical weapons is reduced by the value of your Damage Reduction to a minimum of 1.
rows: The weapon gains the Thrown (10/30) property if it doesn't have the Thrown property. If it has the Thrown property, the range increases by 10/30 feet instead.
Your falling speed increases to 520 feet per round while wearing this armor.

The weapon's damage die is reduced by {@dice d2}. Adds the "Special: You can use a bonus action immediately after to make a single melee attack with it. This attack deals {@damage 1d4} slashing damage on a hit".
A weapon with the light property forged from it loses the light property. If the weapon didn't have the light property, it gains the heavy property.

If an Effect moves you against your will along the ground while wearing this armor, you can use your Reaction to reduce the distance you are moved by up to 10 feet. The weight of the armor is increased by 50%.
The weapon gains the Finesse property.
You are considered proficient with this armor even if you lack proficiency.
A Fragile weapon breaks on an attack roll of 1 against an armored target (a target wearing armor or with the natural armor property) if that armor doesn't have the Fragile property.
A Fragile set of armor is destroyed when you take a critical strike from a creature wielding a weapon without the Fragile property.
The weapon's Quality Die when maintained becomes a {@dice d12}.
The armor's Quality Die when maintained becomes a {@dice d12}.

Requires two-handed weapon with reach. The weapon becomes one handed and its base damage die increases by {@damage d2}, but you have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.
A Masterwork weapon gains +1 to attack rolls. Removes the fragile property if present.
A set of Masterwork armor gains a Damage Reduction<sup>DR</sup> value of 2. Removes the fragile property if present.
The armor can be donned or doffed in half as much time
This weapon can hold 1 magical gem crafted by an Enchanter
This armor can hold 1 magical gem crafted by Enchanter.
If a weapon deals bludgeoning damage, it now deals piercing damage.
Attackers that strike you with unarmed strikes or natural weapons take {@damage 1d4} piercing damage. A creature that ends its turn while grappling you takes 1d4 piercing damage.

table.name: Supplemental Modifiers
footnotes: * Supplemental Materials are doubled for weapons with the two-handed property or armor
<sup>Magic</sup> Magic: Difficulty modifier is reduced to +3 if combined with Mithral or Adamantine material modifiers.
rows: Weapon adds +1 to attack and damage rolls.
This weapon is considered silvered for the purposes of overcoming damage resistance.
